overview_of_class: Internal Communications focuses on how organizations can accomplish their goals and build stronger brands by getting employees to understand the direction and how they help create and further the brand. In this class, students  learn how to engage and persuade employees to become brand ambassadors with customers, the community where they work and among fellow employees.  It's not an easy task.  Today's workforce is more diverse than ever, and companies continue to seek greater diversity. There are different levels, education, ethnic and generational cohorts in most companies.  There are different languages spoken.  Employees may be in one location, spread out around the globe, or a growing number working in a virtual capacity or in constant motion.    Reaching employees and communicating effectively with them requires a variety of skills.  Students learn how to understand the dynamic employee audience, how to determine what's important, how to create a workplace environment conducive to mobilizing the employees to act effectively and in concert, how to deal with change in the organization and in the work environment, and how to lead when there's a great deal of turbulence and uncertainty.

overview_of_class: Data Management helps students understand how to prepare data sets that can be analyzed with the methods covered in IMC 451, 451-1 and IMC 460. The course will devote a significant amount of time on understanding relational databases which consist of multiple, inter-related tables. The course will cover SAS programming in detail and includes a module on Structured Query Language (SQL). The programming strategies covered in this class could be implemented in other programming languages such as Python, R or SPSS. Students should be able to pass the SAS Base Programming certification exam by week 8, and the SAS Advanced Programming certification exam after the quarter is over.
